channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: Federation Plan Offers South More Autonomy
item.description: Yemen’s president approved turning the country into a federal state, giving the south more autonomy. But some southerners are insisting on a separate state.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: The Lede: Olympic Torch-Bearer Apologizes for Racist Obama Tweet
item.description: Irina Rodnina, a former Russian skater and current lawmaker, apologized while saying her Twitter account had been hacked.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Irina Rodnina and Vladislav Tretiak, two of Russia's most decorated athletes, lit the Olympic caldron to open the Sochi Games on Friday.

item.title: Swiss Vote Seen as Sign of Far Right’s Power in Europe
item.description: Some leaders said a referendum limiting the number of foreigners allowed to live and work in Switzerland was a retreat from European integration.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: European Union foreign ministers met in Brussels on Monday to discuss the Swiss immigration vote and the political crisis in Ukraine.

item.title: World Briefing: Taiwan and China Ready to Begin Landmark Talks
item.description: The two sides will hold their highest-level talks since splitting amid a civil war 65 years ago, with hopes of increasing contacts and easing tensions.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Erik Blegvad, Children’s Book Artist, Dies at 90
item.description: Mr. Blegvad, a prolific illustrator, possessed a style that was comfortingly Old World; he worked primarily in meticulous pen and ink, with some forays into watercolor.
item.category: "This Little Pig-a-Wig and Other Rhymes About Pigs" (Book)
item.dc:creator: By MARGALIT FOX
item.media:description: Erik Blegvad, seen in 1986, was a prolific illustrator.

item.title: The Lede: Journalist Killed by Flare Thrown During Rio Protest
item.description: Officials in Rio de Janeiro announced that a cameraman who was struck in the head by an explosive device during street clashes on Thursday was “clinically brain-dead.”
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Memories of Home as Hollande Visits United States
item.description: On Monday, President François Hollande of France toured Monticello, the Virginia home of Thomas Jefferson, who, President Obama said, was “a Francophile through and through.”
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Presidents Obama and François Hollande of France toured Monticello, Thomas Jefferson’s home in Virginia, with Leslie Greene Bowman, president of the Thomas Jefferson Foundation.

item.title: Suicide Bomb Trainer in Iraq Accidentally Blows Up His Class
item.description: Twenty-two militants at a training session were killed after a commander mistakenly used an armed belt during a demonstration.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN and TIM ARANGO

item.title: Istanbul Journal: Pirate Radio Gives Voice to Opposition Fighting Assad
item.description: Over a dozen opposition radio stations broadcast into Syria, and some activists try to keep their signals, and themselves, alive by running operations from places like Turkey.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wasfi Massarani, a Syrian singer, on Radio Watan, one of more than a dozen radio stations that have sprung up in opposition to President Bashar al-Assad.

item.title: Hyundai Sends Luxury Model to Challenge Europe’s Auto Stalwarts
item.description: The South Korean automaker is already marketing a high-end model in the United States, but cracking the European market of BMW and Mercedes is another thing.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC PFANNER
item.media:description: A new Hyundai Genesis was unveiled at a ceremony last November in Seoul, South Korea.

item.title: As Second Round of Syrian Talks Begin, U.N.’s Mediator Steps Cautiously
item.description: Government and opposition delegations returned for a second round of peace negotiations after the first round ended 10 days ago with little progress.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: Louay Safi, a spokesman for Syria’s main opposition group, at a press briefing in Geneva on Monday.

item.title: Russia and China Skip Security Council Meeting on Humanitarian Aid to Syria
item.description: A Russian diplomat said a measure forcing all sides in the Syrian civil war to allow access to humanitarian groups would have no practical impact.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: The Lede: Turkey Deports Journalist for Criticizing Government on Twitter
item.description: Turkey deported an Azerbaijani journalist on Friday for “posting tweets against high-level state officials,” according to an Interior Ministry order obtained by his newspaper, the English-language daily Today’s Zaman.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU and ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Global Health: Poor Nations Seek New Hepatitis C Drug
item.description: Doctors Without Borders is hoping to get poor nations a cheaper version of a new pill that can cure hepatitis C and will cost $84,000 a treatment in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: An electron micrograph of a hepatitis C virus.

item.title: Camels Had No Business in Genesis
item.description: Camels appear in stories of early Jewish patriarchs in the Bible, even though it was before the animals’ time, evidence that writing or editing of the book happened long after the events it narrates.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD
item.media:description: The annual camel race in the desert of Wadi Rum, Jordan, in 2007. Radiocarbon dating was used to pinpoint the earliest known domesticated camels in Israel to the 10th century B.C.— decades after the kingdom of David, according to the Bible.

item.title: British Politicians Blame One Another for Regional Flooding
item.description: Members of Parliament and an emergency agency passed blame back and forth about who was to blame for Britain’s lack of preparedness after thousands of houses were damaged.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: Flooded properties in the village of Moorland in Somerset, England, on Monday.

item.title: Furious Bosnians Shut Down Central Sarajevo
item.description: Antigovernment protests build and spread to other cities as demonstrators vented anger, urging those in authority to “resign today.”
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Ziyah Gafic for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some 1,000 antigovernment protesters shut down the center of Sarajevo on Monday.

item.title: Spain Seeks to Place Curbs on Law Allowing Judges to Pursue Cases Globally
item.description: After crusading judges in Spain ordered international warrants for a former premier and an ex-president from China, an important trade partner, the Spanish Parliament will debate halting the practice.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: On Monday, the National Court in Spain ordered international warrants for Jiang Zemin, left, China’s former president, and a former prime minister, Li Peng, relating to a case on Tibet.

item.title: Listening Post: From ‘Least Diplomatic Diplomat,’ Salty Peek at Trans-Atlantic Strains
item.description: A state visit by President François Hollande of France will bring talk of common values, but a leaked recording offers a more accurate snapshot of the complicated relationship.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Victoria J. Nuland, assistant secretary of state for European affairs, on Friday.

item.title: World Briefing: Flooding and Landslides in Burundi Kill Dozens
item.description: At least 60 people died and dozens were injured after torrential rains that began on Sunday and continued into Monday.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Nude Sunbathers Ordered to Cover Up
item.description: The police in Sanya, a seaside city in the country’s far south, are warning old men not to tan naked on a beach there.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Sunbathers at a beach in Sanya, Hainan Province, watch as government officials post a notice on the ban on public nudity.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: February 10
item.description: A child taking a shower inside a public ground in Mumbai, Maharashtra.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: India Ink: Four Foreign Tourists Arrested After Knife Attack in Goa
item.description: Two Russians and two Egyptians are in custody after an altercation at a beach shack that left a waiter with a slashed face.
item.dc:creator: By SHARON FERNANDES

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Leena Gita Reghunath, Editorial Manager at The Caravan Magazine
item.description: The journalist spoke with India Ink about the startling revelations in her story about Swami Aseemanand, a former Hindu nationalist activist who has been charged with plotting five terrorist attacks, which collectively killed 119 people.
item.dc:creator: By RAKSHA KUMAR
item.media:description: The cover page of February issue of The Caravan.

item.title: Judges Weigh Evidence in Case Against Congolese Rebel
item.description: The judges at the International Criminal Court in The Hague are deciding if there is sufficient evidence to try Bosco Ntaganda of war crimes.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: Bosco Ntaganda, known by the nickname the Terminator, appeared at the International Criminal Court in The Hague on Monday.
